Why do people disagree so much about climate change? How can you tell fact from fiction in the debate? How do we know climate change is happening and what are the causes? Climate change is now an issue confronting many disciplines, from architecture, engineering and business through to environmental science, public health, law and economics. This online course will draw on a broad collection of UNSW experts to cover the basics of climate change science, as well as a selection of key related areas from psychology, law, politics, economics, energy supply, ethics and health. A range of perspectives on the nature of these challenges will be treated with a critical analysis approach, as well hands-on engagement with the peer review process, highlighting its role in the scientific process. This course is an online-only offering. Take a look at our short introduction video.

This is assessed by course staff at the end of the semester, based on the quality, frequency and constructiveness of student's written discussions in the online forum. Students who are not contributing appropriately in the first few weeks will receive some feedback encouraging them to contribute.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"332b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"332b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3b2b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f3961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3b2b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f3961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3b2b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f3961984","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb2b7cccdbb1e810be4672f5f3961986","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group-based peer review exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The purpose of the group-based peer review exercise is to familiarize students with the peer review process. In groups, students will perform three tasks each worth 10% of the final grade:

1. Given a paper, media article or similar, write a critical appraisal piece

2. Write peer reviews of three (3) other critical appraisals from other groups

3. Respond to peer reviews and amend original critical appraisal

Big Fat Myths","description":"

Weight loss fads in the form of diets and exercise regimes (with mostly unrealistic claims) are ubiquitous in modern day life; however, there is surprising ignorance and confusion about how we lose weight, with most people unable to answer the simplest question: when you lose weight, where does the fat go? Popular (incorrect) answers include energy, heat, faeces and sweat. Surprisingly, this question has also baffled health professionals including general practitioners, dietitians and professional trainers.


This course will lift the veil on weight loss by tracing every atom you eat into and out of your body, and you will learn the fate of fat during weight loss, that is, it is converted to carbon dioxide and water and exits your body mainly through your lungs. Along the way, you will also learn how humans convert foods into useful energy, what exactly is happening in your bodies during weight loss and weight gain, and by the end you will be able to critically examine popular weight loss claims as well as your own diet and lifestyle. Diet myths and wellness nonsense topple like dominoes along the way.


No prior scientific knowledge is assumed as we aim to provide you with the knowledge to answer this big, fat myth.


Note: Students enrolled in a Faculty of Science program should not take this course but can enrol in the equivalent course, BABS1111.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[{"dependent_type":{"label":null,"value":null},"ai_cl_id":{"value":"GENS1112","cl_id":"d84879701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb93","key":"code"},"association_type":{"label":"Equivalents","value":"9"},"association_desc":"","associated_ai_cl_id":{"value":"BABS1112","cl_id":"0d963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb71","key":"code"},"cl_id":"2878bd701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb55","assoc_credit_points":"6","assoc_active":"true","assoc_title":"Genetics and Society","assoc_cl_id":"0d963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb71","assoc_short_title":"BABS1112 - Genetics and Society","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/BABS1112","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"BABS1112","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENS1112 - Genetics and Society","description":"

Since the release of the first human genome about two decades ago, our understanding of genetics has improved significantly. Facilitated by massive developments in DNA sequencing technologies, we now live in a society where genetics and genomics, and applications thereof, have become household terms. We hear about genetically modified food crops with extra nutrients or drought resistance, and personalised medicine offers new hope (or hype) in health care. Genetic tools are routinely used in forensics and gene doping is a growing concern at sporting events. Synthetic biology promises new frontiers of technology, and the day we use DNA for data storage is not that far away.


What does this all mean? Is it ethical? Is it legal? What are the social implications that come with these applications?


This interactive, fully online course will introduce students to fundamental genetic concepts using real life applications and implications of genetics while providing an opportunity to get hands-on experience in analysing and interpreting genetic data. Students will be encouraged to critically evaluate the ethical, legal and social implications of genetic advances throughout the course. On completion, we anticipate the students will be better prepared to survive in the “genome generation” and participate in informed debate and decision making with regard to incorporating genetic interventions in everyday life.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d048b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb76","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion forum","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

This task aims to assess the ability of students to reflect on genetic applications and interventions and develop an evidence-based argument around the ethical, legal and social implications of these applications and interventions. There will be a discussion forum for each module (each week), and students will be required to make a minimum of two posts per week; one post responding to a question set by the course convenor and one post responding to a posting made by another student. The forums will be facilitated and monitored by the course convenor. In addition to their efforts every week, five posts will be randomly selected at the end of the term for each student, to be assessed for the quality of the postings, using a marking rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2048b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb79","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2448b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb78","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2848b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb7a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2848b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb81","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This task will assess students’ ability to follow the scientific method to investigate a real-life problem using DNA technologies and their ability to interpret the results obtained. It is based on the online practical component of the course that requires students to analyse a set of DNA sequencing or genotyping results and answer a series of questions based on their observations. Students will be introduced to the task in Week 1 and will have the opportunity to conduct the work throughout the whole term with the final report due in Week 10. Students will need to submit their report via Turnitin and feedback will be provided on the returned work during the university grade release period.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2048b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb7a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2848b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb79","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6c48b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb8b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

This task aims to assess the ability of students to identify genetic applications and interventions as reported in media and apply basic genetic theories and concepts learnt in the course to evaluate how they are represented in the media. Students will be provided with a list of media articles or documentaries where real-life scenarios of genetics applications or interventions are discussed. Students will choose one application or intervention and prepare a critical review on how the application or intervention is presented in the media. Students can choose to present the critical review in a written essay or in a video. This assignment is due in Week 7 and feedback will be provided via Moodle (Turnitin).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2048b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb79","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2448b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb78","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2848b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb79","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2848b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb7a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e048b9701b826410d5fb0fabdc4bcb86","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

These quizzes will focus on the genetic concepts and applications covered during the week and will be held each week except in Week 6 (flexi week). The quizzes will be available online via Moodle Quiz and will consist of 10 multiple-choice or short answer type questions and students will be allowed to attempt the quiz once only. There will be a time limit for the quizzes to prevent students from consulting any reference material. The time allowed should be ample for them to read and answer all the questions. Feedback will be released via Moodle Quiz once the students have completed each quiz.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENS2025 - Introduction to Airborne Drone Management","description":"

Airborne drones (unmanned aerial vehicles (or remotely piloted aircraft (RPA)) of varying shapes and sizes are permeating the civil aviation sector across recreational, commercial and research activities. The professional ability to safely and efficiently operate and manage airborne drones requires fundamental aviation knowledge. This course will introduce these fundamentals of RPA management to students through a suite of topics including basic aeronautical knowledge, RPA ethics and law, human factors and safety, logistics and operations, and RPA research methods. The course will emphasise practical applications of the concepts and tools introduced through select case studies and realistic mission planning for operations involving commercial and research activities.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a46581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The exam covers all topics in the course. The purpose of the exam is to test student understanding of the concepts and tools learnt in remotely piloted aircraft governance, operations and research. Students will be encouraged to demonstrate their understanding of theoretical knowledge through the use of original examples. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1c6581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"546581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"906581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"a86581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dc6581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"006581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short answer questions","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This assignment covers the main topics introduced in Unit1-6. This will be delivered as a number of online short answer assessment items during the semester to act as both a mechanism for students to check their understanding of the material and as a small assessment item. The emphasis will be on understanding the core concepts the course subsequently builds on in the later units.

\n

Grading will be completed within 2 weeks of submission. Feedback from this assessment will be used to guide and teach students towards the case study report and final exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1c6581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"546581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"906581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dc6581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c6581ffdb391c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Case study report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This report will require students to apply concepts learnt to plan and assess a realistic remotely piloted aircraft mission for commercial activity. The assignment requires students consult a mix of multimedia, industry, government, and academic sources. Grading will be completed within 3 weeks of submission. 

\n

Student work will be judged on the comprehensiveness of the plan, gathering of correct information and accuracy in the use of the information. Students will be asked to pitch the mission proposal in a form of short video, which will be assessed on presentation clarity and accuracy.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENS4008 - Nuclear Arms, Peace and Global Governance","description":"

Students are invited to study and discuss various questions concerning nuclear weapons, and the more general problem of preventing war. We look at the international political system, warfare and the arms race. We ask how a nuclear bomb actually works, and what its effects are likely to be. The associated issues of nuclear safeguards and the nuclear power industry are treated briefly. We study nuclear strategies, and then review attempts to control nuclear arms, particularly the Non Proliferation Treaty. We discuss institutions of collective security aimed at preserving peace, including the European Union and the United Nations. Finally, we discuss steps towards improved governance at the global level, through which we may eventually remove the threat of nuclear weapons entirely.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0f77f0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961912","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Tutorials","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"24","description":"

Each week for 8 weeks, students are asked to post answers to a set of questions related to the lectures, one original post, and one in response to another’s post. Feedback is given individually online, and in a general washup message posted on the Moodle site for that week.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4b77f0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3677b0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"16","description":"

Four multiple choice quizzes are set on the material discussed in the lectures, worth 4% each. Marking is automatic, and no feedback is given.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8377b0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cf77b0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3677b0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619c2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Blog Post","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are asked to post an online discussion of a topic of their choice related to the course of about one page in length, and also post a comment on another’s original post, as in the tutorials. Feedback is given online.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0f77b0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4b77f0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b277b0bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The final course assignment is an essay. Students are asked to write an essay of around 2000 - 3000 words on a topic associated with the course. A list of possible topics will appear on the Moodle site, but they are encouraged to find their own topic. Feedback is written on the essay, which students may collect after the course is completed.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENS4015 - Brave New World: Science Fiction, Science Fact and the Future","description":"

This wholly Internet-delivered course aims to give a big picture overview of the physical sciences at the dawn of the 21st century and beyond. The most common interface between the general public and science is often through science fiction; hence, science fiction is used as a teaching aid to stimulate student interest and as a starting point from which to communicate the science, and its likely future development. This course also examines the interaction between science and society, encouraging students to consider how culture influences science and vice versa. This course aims to provide students with the level of scientific and technological literacy required to take an informed part in debate on important scientific issues.


The areas covered are: the physics of space and time; astronomy; space travel and exploration; astrobiology: life in the Universe; computers & robotics, artificial intelligence & human intelligence; the future of the human race; the future of planet Earth, including an examination of the physics of climate change; a brief look at the place of physics in popular culture is included.


Note: Students enrolled in a Faculty of Science program should not take this course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dc5be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619e1","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Discussions and tutorials","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

During week 2 through to week 9 students will need to contribute weekly to on-line discussions (tutorials). There are 8 online tutorials in total, and contributions will be due by the end of the week in which the tutorial is posted. All 8 tutorial discussions will be of equal weight. Feedback: Marks will be posted for the tutorial discussion posting one week after the close of the tutorial.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"485be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"945be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d05be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"334be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

There will be three online quizzes. The quizzes will generally open on 0900 of the Monday of the week they are due, will be open for one week, closing at 2359 hrs on the following Sunday (i.e. just before midnight). The quizzes are due: Quiz 1 due Week 3; Quiz 2 due Week 6; Quiz 3 due Week 9. Feedback: The quizzes are marked automatically and students will have results as soon as submitted.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"485be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"945be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"485be26bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619b9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Blog Posting","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will write a 300 to 400-word posting on topic chosen from the set of available topics. Students will have the chance to suggest topics on which they would like to blog. To get full marks, students must make a comment on another student’s blog posting. The assignment opens around Week 3, and the Blog posting due around end Week 4. The comment on another student’s blog posting due around end Week 5. Students will receive marks and feedback on the assignment within about 1 week of the due date.

contentlets.description:
This wholly Internet-delivered course aims to give a big picture overview of the physical sciences at the dawn of the 21st century and beyond. The most common interface between the general public and science is often through science fiction; hence, science fiction is used as a teaching aid to stimulate student interest and as a starting point from which to communicate the science, and its likely future development. This course also examines the interaction between science and society, encouraging students to consider how culture influences science and vice versa. This course aims to provide students with the level of scientific and technological literacy required to take an informed part in debate on important scientific issues.

The areas covered are: the physics of space and time; astronomy; space travel and exploration; astrobiology: life in the Universe; computers & robotics, artificial intelligence & human intelligence; the future of the human race; the future of planet Earth, including an examination of the physics of climate change; a brief look at the place of physics in popular culture is included.

Note: Students enrolled in a Faculty of Science program should not take this course.
contentlets.title: Brave New World: Science Fiction, Science Fact and the Future

Aviation is a high-profile industry that influences modern society at many levels. The aviation system comprises a complex array of human and mechanical interactions - known as a sociotechnical system - providing a myriad of social and technical challenges. Additionally, many seemingly unrelated industries and groups are influenced by aviation. This course provides the opportunity for students to challenge industry dogmas and consider solutions to the problems facing contemporary aviation. By utilising the variety of skills and backgounds that General Studies courses bring together, students develop an understanding of the main issues in complex, highly reliable mass-transport systems. The course also allows students to investigate how the key issues interrelate both within the industry and with entities external to aviation; this course does not simply focus on problems for the industry, but collates the issues that affect the providers, users and third parties involved in the system. The course provides an explicit treatment of subsectors often overshadowed by the airline livery, namely, aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO), airports, online/off-line travel agents, and global distribution systems (GDS). The contemporary issues are organised around four major areas: competition, capacity, safety and the future. 


Note: Students enrolled in a Faculty of Science program should not take this course.

As a result, the following assessment items are examples employed from 2011 and will change in 2012. Write a 1200 word report about aviation fuel pricing and the local and global effects that cause fuel price fluctuations. This requires the incorporation of Human Factors in the design of the report. ie. charts, diagrams, pictures, creative layout etc. What measures do airlines take to try and control pricing? How do fuel levies work? How do airlines buy their fuel? What slice of an airlines operating budget is fuel? What safety factors are vital regarding fuel supplies and why? This is a broad topic with current volatility. Do not limit yourself to the questions above. Think "outside the box" when completing this assignment.

Feedback is provided via the grading tool in BlackBoard9.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3633aaa3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"be33aaa3dbf99850eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f633aaa3dbf99850eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6a336aa3dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619f6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written Assignment - Incident Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"On 4 November 2010, at 0157 Universal Coordinated Time (UTC), an Airbus A380 aircraft, registered VH-OQA (OQA), being operated as Qantas flight 32, departed from runway 20 centre (20C) at Changi Airport, Singapore for Sydney, New South Wales. On board the aircraft were five flight crew, 24 cabin crew and 440 passengers (a total of 469 persons on board). Following a normal takeoff, the crew retracted the landing gear and flaps. The crew reported that, while maintaining 250 kts in the climb and passing 7,000 ft above mean sea level, they heard two almost coincident 'loud bangs', followed shortly after by indications of a failure of the No 2 engine. The crew advised Singapore Air Traffic Control of the situation and were provided with radar vectors to a holding pattern. The crew undertook a series of actions before returning the aircraft to land at Singapore. There were no reported injuries to the crew or passengers on the aircraft. There were reports of minor injuries to two persons on Batam Island, Indonesia. Repairs to the Qantas A380 that suffered extensive damage from a midair engine explosion in November will begin in the next few weeks. Estimates of the cost of the work reach as high as $150 million. The A380 has been stored in a hangar at Singapore's Changi Airport while Qantas and the aircraft's manufacturer, Airbus, assessed the best options for repairing the double-decker plane. Its windows and exterior openings have been covered and silica gel used to prevent the A380 from corroding in the tropical heat. ABC 4 Corners featured this incident recently. You can watch this programme here in 2 parts. 4 Corners Part 1 4 Corners Part 2 Write a 2000 word essay on this incident. What has been the impact on Qantas? Where do Rolls Royce stand? What is the effect on the world fleet of Rolls Royce engined Airbus A380's? Your work must be uploaded as a pdf or MS Word file.

Workplace Safety","description":"

The ways in which work can affect people's health, safety and well-being is an important consideration for all organisations. Accordingly, an understanding of workplace safety issues is important for students pursuing careers in any industry. This course explores the legal frameworks, current methodologies and issues of best practice in the prevention and management of workplace hazards. The course uses a variety of media in course material and assessment, including websites, videos and case studies, and builds on students own workplace experiences. It is anticipated that students will gain an appreciation of current legislation and codes of practice, identify different types of workplace hazards and understand how they can affect people; and be able to apply the risk management approach to workplace hazards.


Note: Students enrolled in a Faculty of Science program should not take this course.
